values.description: I committed a small change directly to pull request #234 in 34d00d8 that initializes the battery charge `q` along with `q0` in the `Configure` function. This is a bit bigger of a change that uses a simple computation for state of charge: `SOC = q / c`. The battery drains much more slowly now.
values.title: Simpler state of charge computation -> pull request #234

summary.raw: I committed a small change directly to pull request #234 in 34d00d8 that initializes the battery charge `q` along with `q0` in the `Configure` function. This is a bit bigger of a change that uses a simple computation for state of charge: `SOC = q / c`. The battery drains much more slowly now.
summary.html: I committed a small change directly to pull request #234 in 34d00d8 that initializes the battery charge q along with q0 in the Configure function. This is a bit bigger of a change that uses a simple computation for state of charge: SOC = q / c. The battery drains much more slowly now.

values.description:
Most of the code is ported from the sensors system. The idea is that the same component will be shared by both sensors and gui systems.

A Scene3D system that makes use of this rendering component will come in a separate PR.

Also updated the SceneManager to parse PBR material parameters. You can test with `examples/worlds/fuel_textured_mesh.sdf`. Requires [ign-fuel-tools pull request #95](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-fuel-tools/pull-requests/95/fix-pbr-material-uri/diff). See screenshot below. The human model in the gui render window does not have textures yet and will be addressed in the Scene3D system.

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/2443792578-Screenshot_from_2019-05-01_17-33-06.png)
values.title: Add rendering component

A Scene3D system that makes use of this rendering component will come in a separate PR.

values.description:
This will be used by the GUI system, see pull request #285.

---

* Offer `/world/<name>/state` service, which fills the state message on demand
* Periodically publish state on `/world/<name>/state`. Ideally, this will eventually publish only when there are state changes, but currently we can't know when components changed, so we're publishing periodically at 60Hz.
values.title: [Blueprint] State broadcast

summary.raw:
This will be used by the GUI system, see pull request #285.

---

* Offer `/world/<name>/state` service, which fills the state message on demand
* Periodically publish state on `/world/<name>/state`. Ideally, this will eventually publish only when there are state changes, but currently we can't know when components changed, so we're publishing periodically at 60Hz.
summary.html:
This will be used by the GUI system, see pull request #285.

  • Offer /world/<name>/state service, which fills the state message on demand
  • Periodically publish state on /world/<name>/state. Ideally, this will eventually publish only when there are state changes, but currently we can't know when components changed, so we're publishing periodically at 60Hz.

values.description:
Since pull request #292, loading a world without models hangs, because the scene broadcaster doesn't offer services until entities have been loaded.

Checking when the world entity is created solves the problem, and it looks like `camera_sensor.sdf` still works well.

@iche033 , mind taking a look?

FYI @nkoenig
values.title: [Blueprint] Fix Scene3D loading empty world

summary.raw:
Since pull request #292, loading a world without models hangs, because the scene broadcaster doesn't offer services until entities have been loaded.

Checking when the world entity is created solves the problem, and it looks like `camera_sensor.sdf` still works well.

@iche033 , mind taking a look?

FYI @nkoenig
summary.html:
Since pull request #292, loading a world without models hangs, because the scene broadcaster doesn't offer services until entities have been loaded.

Checking when the world entity is created solves the problem, and it looks like camera_sensor.sdf still works well.

@iche033 , mind taking a look?

FYI @nkoenig

values.description:
Throttled debug messages so it's not too spammy and updated the command line tool.

I started adding instructions to the example world, but the blue vehicle is never stopping. Without throttling the messages, this is the last update:

~~~
[Dbg] [LinearBatteryPlugin.cc:282] Battery: linear_battery
[Dbg] [LinearBatteryPlugin.cc:283] PowerLoads().size(): 1
[Dbg] [LinearBatteryPlugin.cc:285] voltage: -0.163431
[Dbg] [LinearBatteryPlugin.cc:286] state of charge: 0.249608 (q 0.299755)
~~~

The battery goes negative while the SoC is still 25%. Should the car stop? @mabelmzhang @scpeters

values.description:
Distributed simulation has not been working on default since pull request #292.

Pull request #315 fixes it, but a caveat, probably introduced by pull request #285, is that all secondaries must start before the primary for the GUI to work. Headless mode is not affected.

This PR updates the documentation accordingly. In the future, it will be nice to support secondaries and primary starting in any order.
values.title: [Blueprint] Fix distributed sim documentation

summary.raw:
Distributed simulation has not been working on default since pull request #292.

Pull request #315 fixes it, but a caveat, probably introduced by pull request #285, is that all secondaries must start before the primary for the GUI to work. Headless mode is not affected.

This PR updates the documentation accordingly. In the future, it will be nice to support secondaries and primary starting in any order.
summary.html:
Distributed simulation has not been working on default since pull request #292.

Pull request #315 fixes it, but a caveat, probably introduced by pull request #285, is that all secondaries must start before the primary for the GUI to work. Headless mode is not affected.

This PR updates the documentation accordingly. In the future, it will be nice to support secondaries and primary starting in any order.

values.description:
We are currently using stream operators to serialize components. This can be problematic if end users define their own overloads for a given stream operator. For example, we currently define a stream operator for `std::vector<double>`. If an end user wants to print out a `std::vector<double>` they might define a stream operator that outputs the values with, say, 2 digit precision. Since the overload is already defined, I'm not sure the user will be able to. If they can, our serialization won't work properly.

This PR takes a different approach where a Serializer class is passed in as the third template argument to `component::Component`. Apart from mitigating the problem mentioned above, this also allows us to share Serializers among Components while still being able to provide different serializers for two different components that happen to have the same underlying data type.

Also in this PR `component::Component` now uses compiler defined constructors and assignment operators. I believe this works since [sdformat PR #524](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/524)
values.title: [Blueprint] Serializer classes

summary.raw:
We are currently using stream operators to serialize components. This can be problematic if end users define their own overloads for a given stream operator. For example, we currently define a stream operator for `std::vector<double>`. If an end user wants to print out a `std::vector<double>` they might define a stream operator that outputs the values with, say, 2 digit precision. Since the overload is already defined, I'm not sure the user will be able to. If they can, our serialization won't work properly.

This PR takes a different approach where a Serializer class is passed in as the third template argument to `component::Component`. Apart from mitigating the problem mentioned above, this also allows us to share Serializers among Components while still being able to provide different serializers for two different components that happen to have the same underlying data type.

Also in this PR `component::Component` now uses compiler defined constructors and assignment operators. I believe this works since [sdformat PR #524](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/524)
summary.html:
We are currently using stream operators to serialize components. This can be problematic if end users define their own overloads for a given stream operator. For example, we currently define a stream operator for std::vector<double>. If an end user wants to print out a std::vector<double> they might define a stream operator that outputs the values with, say, 2 digit precision. Since the overload is already defined, I'm not sure the user will be able to. If they can, our serialization won't work properly.

This PR takes a different approach where a Serializer class is passed in as the third template argument to component::Component. Apart from mitigating the problem mentioned above, this also allows us to share Serializers among Components while still being able to provide different serializers for two different components that happen to have the same underlying data type.

Also in this PR component::Component now uses compiler defined constructors and assignment operators. I believe this works since sdformat PR #524

values.description: This is a work in progress porting the `gazebo_motor_model` from rotors_simulator to an ignition gazebo system. I've started by duplicating and renaming the `ApplyJointForce` system (e77f0b1) and copying the [UpdateForcesAndMoments()](https://github.com/ethz-asl/rotors_simulator/blob/master/rotors_gazebo_plugins/src/gazebo_motor_model.cpp#L390) function into it (ed4c807), and trying to port pieces over so that it will compile (various commits). Once it compiles, I will work on connecting the publishers and subscribers.
values.title: [Blueprint] Multicopter motor model

summary.raw: This is a work in progress porting the `gazebo_motor_model` from rotors_simulator to an ignition gazebo system. I've started by duplicating and renaming the `ApplyJointForce` system (e77f0b1) and copying the [UpdateForcesAndMoments()](https://github.com/ethz-asl/rotors_simulator/blob/master/rotors_gazebo_plugins/src/gazebo_motor_model.cpp#L390) function into it (ed4c807), and trying to port pieces over so that it will compile (various commits). Once it compiles, I will work on connecting the publishers and subscribers.
summary.html: This is a work in progress porting the gazebo_motor_model from rotors_simulator to an ignition gazebo system. I've started by duplicating and renaming the ApplyJointForce system (e77f0b1) and copying the UpdateForcesAndMoments() function into it (ed4c807), and trying to port pieces over so that it will compile (various commits). Also fixes a few spelling mistakes.

values.description:
I ran into a linking problem while working on: #!/ignitionrobotics/ign-launch/pull-requests/22.

The gazebo gui plugins would not find the gazebo gui system without this change.

To test:

1. Install #!/ignitionrobotics/ign-launch/pull-requests/22
2. Don't install this PR.
3. Run: `ign launch -v 4 plugins/gazebo_plugins.ign`

You should see messages like:
```
Error while loading the library [/home/nkoenig/local/lib/ign-gazebo-2/plugins/gui/libScene3D.so]: /home/nkoenig/local/lib/ign-gazebo-2/plugins/gui/libScene3D.so: undefined symbol: _ZTIN8ignition6gazebo2v29GuiSystemE
[GUI] [Err] [Application.cc:334] Failed to load plugin [Scene3D] : couldn't load library on path [/home/nkoenig/local/lib/ign-gazebo-2/plugins/gui/libScene3D.so].
```
values.title: Fix gui plugin linking issue

```
Error while loading the library [/home/nkoenig/local/lib/ign-gazebo-2/plugins/gui/libScene3D.so]: /home/nkoenig/local/lib/ign-gazebo-2/plugins/gui/libScene3D.so: undefined symbol: _ZTIN8ignition6gazebo2v29GuiSystemE
[GUI] [Err] [Application.cc:334] Failed to load plugin [Scene3D] : couldn't load library on path [/home/nkoenig/local/lib/ign-gazebo-2/plugins/gui/libScene3D.so].
```

values.description:
### Summary

1\. `SceneBroadcaster.cc` is modified to have a new publisher on the new topic `/world/<world_name>/dynamic_pose/info`. This new topic was needed because simply publishing non-static models wasn't enough to reduce file size - `visual`s and `light`s were still being published at 60 hertz and logged in `/pose/info`. This new topic only publishes poses of non-static Models and poses of Links of non-static Models.

2\. A new plugin parameter `dynamic_pose_hertz` is added to `SceneBroadcaster` to control the rate at which dynamic poses are published. Default is 60, which is the original rate for `/world/<world_name>/pose/info`.

E.g.

```
<plugin filename="libignition-gazebo-scene-broadcaster-system.so"
  name="ignition::gazebo::systems::SceneBroadcaster">
  <dynamic_pose_hertz>10</dynamic_pose_hertz>
</plugin>
```

Note: Currently, nothing static is published to the `dynamic_pose/info` topic, not even at the beginning. That can be added if we think necessary. The only consumer of this topic is logging, and since logging playback reads the SDF in the log file, we are assuming that nobody would want the static objects' poses on the `dynamic_pose` topic. The static objects' poses can always be read from the vanilla `pose/info`.

### Result

To test, two diff-drive vehicles were added to the `tunnel_qual_ign.sdf` SubT world \(I tested using a modified version with plugins and gui that can be run with `ign gazebo`, because I can't get the `ign launch` version to show the tunnels\).

Vehicles are rotating in place for an infinite time via the keyboard plugin.

At **10 hertz**, recording for **30 minutes**, file size is **17M**.

At **60 hertz**, recording for **30 minutes**, file size is **87M**.

Tested playback to still work.

### Future work

* Log states instead of poses. Side-effect is that the log files will be even bigger, so some filtering by model name or entity type will be needed.
* Robot models spawned after the world has started are currently not being played back, because they are not in the SDF that is loaded in `LogPlayback`. This can be solved by logging the states instead of poses.
values.title: [Blueprint] Reduce logging file size

summary.raw:
### Summary

1\. `SceneBroadcaster.cc` is modified to have a new publisher on the new topic `/world/<world_name>/dynamic_pose/info`. This new topic was needed because simply publishing non-static models wasn't enough to reduce file size - `visual`s and `light`s were still being published at 60 hertz and logged in `/pose/info`. This new topic only publishes poses of non-static Models and poses of Links of non-static Models.

2\. A new plugin parameter `dynamic_pose_hertz` is added to `SceneBroadcaster` to control the rate at which dynamic poses are published. Default is 60, which is the original rate for `/world/<world_name>/pose/info`.

E.g.

```
<plugin filename="libignition-gazebo-scene-broadcaster-system.so"
  name="ignition::gazebo::systems::SceneBroadcaster">
  <dynamic_pose_hertz>10</dynamic_pose_hertz>
</plugin>
```

Note: Currently, nothing static is published to the `dynamic_pose/info` topic, not even at the beginning. That can be added if we think necessary. The only consumer of this topic is logging, and since logging playback reads the SDF in the log file, we are assuming that nobody would want the static objects' poses on the `dynamic_pose` topic. The static objects' poses can always be read from the vanilla `pose/info`.

### Result

To test, two diff-drive vehicles were added to the `tunnel_qual_ign.sdf` SubT world \(I tested using a modified version with plugins and gui that can be run with `ign gazebo`, because I can't get the `ign launch` version to show the tunnels\).

Vehicles are rotating in place for an infinite time via the keyboard plugin.

At **10 hertz**, recording for **30 minutes**, file size is **17M**.

At **60 hertz**, recording for **30 minutes**, file size is **87M**.

Tested playback to still work.

### Future work

* Log states instead of poses. Side-effect is that the log files will be even bigger, so some filtering by model name or entity type will be needed.
* Robot models spawned after the world has started are currently not being played back, because they are not in the SDF that is loaded in `LogPlayback`. This can be solved by logging the states instead of poses.
summary.html:
Summary

1. SceneBroadcaster.cc is modified to have a new publisher on the new topic /world/<world_name>/dynamic_pose/info. This new topic was needed because simply publishing non-static models wasn't enough to reduce file size - visuals and lights were still being published at 60 hertz and logged in /pose/info. This new topic only publishes poses of non-static Models and poses of Links of non-static Models.

2. A new plugin parameter dynamic_pose_hertz is added to SceneBroadcaster to control the rate at which dynamic poses are published. Default is 60, which is the original rate for /world/<world_name>/pose/info.

E.g.

<plugin filename="libignition-gazebo-scene-broadcaster-system.so"
  name="ignition::gazebo::systems::SceneBroadcaster">
  <dynamic_pose_hertz>10</dynamic_pose_hertz>
</plugin>

Note: Currently, nothing static is published to the dynamic_pose/info topic, not even at the beginning. That can be added if we think necessary. The only consumer of this topic is logging, and since logging playback reads the SDF in the log file, we are assuming that nobody would want the static objects' poses on the dynamic_pose topic. The static objects' poses can always be read from the vanilla pose/info.

Result

To test, two diff-drive vehicles were added to the tunnel_qual_ign.sdf SubT world (I tested using a modified version with plugins and gui that can be run with ign gazebo, because I can't get the ign launch version to show the tunnels).

Vehicles are rotating in place for an infinite time via the keyboard plugin.

At 10 hertz, recording for 30 minutes, file size is 17M.

At 60 hertz, recording for 30 minutes, file size is 87M.

Tested playback to still work.

Future work

  • Log states instead of poses. Side-effect is that the log files will be even bigger, so some filtering by model name or entity type will be needed.
  • Robot models spawned after the world has started are currently not being played back, because they are not in the SDF that is loaded in LogPlayback. This can be solved by logging the states instead of poses.

values.description: This works locally on ubuntu....
values.title: Fix tools

summary.raw: This works locally on ubuntu....
summary.html: This works locally on ubuntu....

values.description:
How to test it:

1. Start recording:

        ign gazebo -v 4 rolling_shapes.sdf --record -r

1. Create a model:

        ign service -s /world/shapes/create --reqtype ignition.msgs.EntityFactory --reptype ignition.msgs.Boolean --timeout 300 --req 'sdf: ''"<?xml version=\"1.0\" ?>''<sdf version=\"1.6\">''<model name=\"spawned_model\">''<link name=\"link\">''<visual name=\"visual\">''<geometry><sphere><radius>1.0</radius></sphere></geometry>''</visual>''<collision name=\"visual\">''<geometry><sphere><radius>1.0</radius></sphere></geometry>''</collision>''</link>''</model>''</sdf>" ''pose: {position: {z: 10}} ''name: "new_name" ''allow_renaming: true'

1. Remove a model:

        ign service -s /world/shapes/remove --reqtype ignition.msgs.Entity --reptype ignition.msgs.Boolean --timeout 300 --req 'name: "box" type: MODEL'

1. Close gazebo

1. Start playback:

        ign gazebo -v 4 -r --playback ~/.ignition/gazebo/log/<timestamp>

1. You should see the spawned model show up, and the deleted model disappear.

---

## Summary:

* Added convenient functions to ECM
* Fix displaying created / removed entities on the entity tree
* Publish state changes on a new topic `/world/<name>/changed_state`. This should eventually be consolidated with the `SceneBroadcaster`'s `/world/<name>/state`, which is being used by the GUI and has different scope and rate.

---

## TODO

* Done
values.title: [Blueprint] Log entity creation and deletion

summary.html:
How to test it:

  1. Start recording:

    ign gazebo -v 4 rolling_shapes.sdf --record -r

  2. Create a model:

    ign service -s /world/shapes/create --reqtype ignition.msgs.EntityFactory --reptype ignition.msgs.Boolean --timeout 300 --req 'sdf: ''"<?xml version=\"1.0\" ?>''<sdf version=\"1.6\">''<model name=\"spawned_model\">''<link name=\"link\">''<visual name=\"visual\">''<geometry><sphere><radius>1.0</radius></sphere></geometry>''</visual>''<collision name=\"visual\">''<geometry><sphere><radius>1.0</radius></sphere></geometry>''</collision>''</link>''</model>''</sdf>" ''pose: {position: {z: 10}} ''name: "new_name" ''allow_renaming: true'

  3. Remove a model:

    ign service -s /world/shapes/remove --reqtype ignition.msgs.Entity --reptype ignition.msgs.Boolean --timeout 300 --req 'name: "box" type: MODEL'

  4. Close gazebo

  5. Start playback:

    ign gazebo -v 4 -r --playback ~/.ignition/gazebo/log/<timestamp>

  6. You should see the spawned model show up, and the deleted model disappear.

Summary:

  • Added convenient functions to ECM
  • Fix displaying created / removed entities on the entity tree
  • Publish state changes on a new topic /world/<name>/changed_state. This should eventually be consolidated with the SceneBroadcaster's /world/<name>/state, which is being used by the GUI and has different scope and rate.

values.description:
There's a lot of pull requests that we've merged to ign-gazebo1. I consolidated some of the battery ones in the changelog; any further edits are welcome.

We can also consider making a 1.2.0 release for acropolis since so much has been merged to this branch.

values.description:
Fix crash when removing an entity selected by the transform tool

To test:

1. launch shapes.sdf: `ign gazebo -v 4 shapes.sdf`
2. Select the entity using the transform tool, e.g. select `box` in translation  mode
3. Delete the selected entity, e.g. `ign service -s /world/shapes/remove --reqtype ignition.msgs.Entity --reptype ignition.msgs.Boolean --timeout 300 --req 'name: "box" type: MODEL'`
values.title: [Blueprint] Fix removing selected entity

values.description:
I loaded all the example worlds and tried the instructions in them.

Fixes include:

* Adding light to dark worlds
* Substituting references to the duck mesh with mesh models from Fuel. We need to keep in mind that these worlds are installed and can't depend on relative paths.
* Added instructions to worlds missing them
* Fixed a few instances of `<updateRate>` -> `<update_rate>`
* Changed the plane on `lights.sdf` to use a plane pose instead of a slanted normal, due to #26
* Enabled `gpu_lidar` test, thanks to @iche033 's tip that the Ogre2 issue had been solved.

---

During my testing, I noticed that about 50% of the time `ign-gazebo` crashes on shutdown, the most common backtrace being this one:

~~~
/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libc.so.6(0x7f7f0fd83f20) [0x7f7f0fd83f20]                                                                                                     
/home/developer/ws/install/ignition-gazebo2/lib/libignition-gazebo2.so.2(_ZNK8ignition6gazebo2v222EntityComponentManager13EntityMatchesEmRKSt3setImSt4lessImESaImEE+0x6d) [0x7f7
f0d5a7afd] /home/developer/ws/src/ign-gazebo/src/EntityComponentManager.cc:443                                                                                     
/home/developer/ws/install/ignition-gazebo2/lib/libignition-gazebo2.so.2(_ZN8ignition6gazebo2v222EntityComponentManager11UpdateViewsEm+0x72) [0x7f7f0d5a81e2] /home/developer/ws
/src/ign-gazebo/src/EntityComponentManager.cc:621                                                                                                                
/home/developer/ws/install/ignition-gazebo2/lib/libignition-gazebo2.so.2(_ZN8ignition6gazebo2v222EntityComponentManager15RemoveComponentEmRKSt4pairImiE+0x26f) [0x7f7f0d5ab5ef]
/home/developer/ws/src/ign-gazebo/src/EntityComponentManager.cc:285                                                                                              
/home/developer/ws/install/ignition-gazebo2/lib/libignition-gazebo2.so.2(_ZN8ignition6gazebo2v222EntityComponentManager15RemoveComponentEmRKm+0x43) [0x7f7f0d5ab6d3] /home/devel
oper/ws/src/ign-gazebo/src/EntityComponentManager.cc:267                                                                                                            
/home/developer/ws/install/ignition-gazebo2/lib/libignition-gazebo2.so.2(_ZN8ignition6gazebo2v222EntityComponentManager8SetStateERKNS_4msgs15SerializedStateE+0x659) [0x7f7f0d5a
d369] /home/developer/ws/src/ign-gazebo/src/EntityComponentManager.cc:828                                                                                           
/home/developer/ws/install/ignition-gazebo2/lib/libignition-gazebo2-gui.so.2(_ZN8ignition6gazebo2v29GuiRunner7OnStateERKNS_4msgs14SerializedStepE+0x3d) [0x7f7f0d913bdd] /home/d
eveloper/ws/src/ign-gazebo/src/gui/GuiRunner.cc:83                                                                                                               
/home/developer/ws/install/ignition-gazebo2/lib/libignition-gazebo2-gui.so.2(_ZN8ignition9transport2v719SubscriptionHandlerINS_4msgs14SerializedStepEE16RunLocalCallbackERKN6goo
gle8protobuf7MessageERKNS1_11MessageInfoE+0x75) [0x7f7f0d922035] /usr/include/c++/8/bits/std_function.h:687                                                      
/home/developer/ws/install/ignition-transport7/lib/libignition-transport7.so.7(_ZN8ignition9transport2v710NodeShared26TriggerSubscriberCallbacksERKNSt7__cxx1112basic_stringIcSt
11char_traitsIcESaIcEEESA_SA_RKNS2_11HandlerInfoE+0x5a7) [0x7f7f0b85b2e7] /home/developer/ws/src/ign-transport/src/NodeShared.cc:463                              
/home/developer/ws/install/ignition-transport7/lib/libignition-transport7.so.7(_ZN8ignition9transport2v710NodeShared13RecvMsgUpdateEv+0x55a) [0x7f7f0b85cfba] /home/developer/ws
/src/ign-transport/src/NodeShared.cc:352                                                                                                                            
/home/developer/ws/install/ignition-transport7/lib/libignition-transport7.so.7(_ZN8ignition9transport2v710NodeShared16RunReceptionTaskEv+0x131) [0x7f7f0b8610f1] /home/developer
/ws/src/ign-transport/src/NodeShared.cc:262 
~~~

I'll address it / ticket an issue once I figure out how to reproduce.

Edit: retargeted to ign-gazebo2.
values.title: [Blueprint] Tweaks to example worlds

summary.raw:
I loaded all the example worlds and tried the instructions in them.

Fixes include:

* Adding light to dark worlds
* Substituting references to the duck mesh with mesh models from Fuel. We need to keep in mind that these worlds are installed and can't depend on relative paths.
* Added instructions to worlds missing them
* Fixed a few instances of `<updateRate>` -> `<update_rate>`
* Changed the plane on `lights.sdf` to use a plane pose instead of a slanted normal, due to #26
* Enabled `gpu_lidar` test, thanks to @iche033 's tip that the Ogre2 issue had been solved.

---

values.title: [Blueprint] Add topic as a system parameter

values.description:
Ran into a problem when running the distributed simulation example scripts, where the primary and secondaries fail to establish connection. The reason was that the heartbeat timeout was too short: 10 \* 100ms = 1s. I increased it to 100 \* 100ms = 10s.

To test

```
cd examples/scripts/distributed_levels
./secondary.sh &
./secondary.sh &
./primary.sh
```

The ign gazebo gui should come up after the last command and you should be able to play the simulation without any problems.
values.title: [Blueprint] Increase distributed simulation peer tracking timeout

summary.raw:
Ran into a problem when running the distributed simulation example scripts, where the primary and secondaries fail to establish connection. The reason was that the heartbeat timeout was too short: 10 \* 100ms = 1s. I increased it to 100 \* 100ms = 10s.

To test

```
cd examples/scripts/distributed_levels
./secondary.sh &
./secondary.sh &
./primary.sh
```

The ign gazebo gui should come up after the last command and you should be able to play the simulation without any problems.
summary.html:
Ran into a problem when running the distributed simulation example scripts, where the primary and secondaries fail to establish connection. The reason was that the heartbeat timeout was too short: 10 * 100ms = 1s. I increased it to 100 * 100ms = 10s.

To test

cd examples/scripts/distributed_levels
./secondary.sh &
./secondary.sh &
./primary.sh

The ign gazebo gui should come up after the last command and you should be able to play the simulation without any problems.

values.description:
Serialization was getting very slow for large worlds with multiple entities and components. To the point that the GUI would be several seconds behind RViz, for example.

This PR changes it so only pose updates are serialized periodically (60Hz), and the full state is only sent if specifically requested or when there are new / deleted entities.

![dronerviz.gif](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/3297896507-dronerviz.gif)
values.title: [Blueprint] Only send pose state periodically

summary.raw:
Serialization was getting very slow for large worlds with multiple entities and components. To the point that the GUI would be several seconds behind RViz, for example.

This PR changes it so only pose updates are serialized periodically (60Hz), and the full state is only sent if specifically requested or when there are new / deleted entities.

![dronerviz.gif](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/3297896507-dronerviz.gif)
summary.html:
Serialization was getting very slow for large worlds with multiple entities and components. To the point that the GUI would be several seconds behind RViz, for example.

This PR changes it so only pose updates are serialized periodically (60Hz), and the full state is only sent if specifically requested or when there are new / deleted entities.

values.description:
Ran into a problem where sometimes we miss the EachNew callbacks responsible for creating the rendering entities, resulting in a white scene. The problem is likely due to the long load time of large worlds. 

Changes made are similar to the `EntityTree` gui system plugin, in which it also checks for pre-existing entities on initialization. I basically duplicated the `EachNew` calls with the `Each` - not very elegant but safer to do than doing code refactoring before the release.
values.title: Check for existing entities in GzScene3D on initialization

summary.raw:
Ran into a problem where sometimes we miss the EachNew callbacks responsible for creating the rendering entities, resulting in a white scene. The problem is likely due to the long load time of large worlds. 

Changes made are similar to the `EntityTree` gui system plugin, in which it also checks for pre-existing entities on initialization. I basically duplicated the `EachNew` calls with the `Each` - not very elegant but safer to do than doing code refactoring before the release.
summary.html:
Ran into a problem where sometimes we miss the EachNew callbacks responsible for creating the rendering entities, resulting in a white scene. The problem is likely due to the long load time of large worlds.

Changes made are similar to the EntityTree gui system plugin, in which it also checks for pre-existing entities on initialization. I basically duplicated the EachNew calls with the Each - not very elegant but safer to do than doing code refactoring before the release.
